subsection.title: Parallel and Perpendicular Lines
subsection.p: Lines that lie in the same plane but never intersect are called parallel lines. It is easy to understand that parallel lines have the same slope.
Lines that intersect at right angles are called perpendicular lines. It is a little harder to see the relationship between the slopes of perpendicular lines.
In the Checkpoint above, note that the product of m_1 and m_2 is -1, that is, m_1 m_2 = \dfrac{1}{2} (-2) = -1 This relationship holds for any pair of perpendicular lines.

statement.p: What do we call two lines that lie in the same plane but never intersect?

answer.p: Lines that intersect at right angles

statement.p: Decide whether the lines 2x+3y=6~~~~~~~~~ \text{and} ~~~~~~~~~3x-2y=6 are parallel, perpendicular, or neither.

solution.p: We could graph the lines, but we can't be sure from a graph if the lines are exactly parallel or exactly perpendicular. A more accurate way to answer the question is to find the slope of each line. To do this we write each equation in slope-intercept form, that is, we solve for y.

The slope of the first line is \dfrac{-2}{3}, and the slope of the second line is \dfrac{3}{2}. The slopes are not equal, so the lines are not parallel. However, the product of the slopes is m_1 m_2 = (\dfrac{-2}{3}) (\dfrac{3}{2}) = -1 so the lines are perpendicular.

assemblage.title: Look Closer

statement.p: What is true about the slopes of parallel lines?
What do we call the slopes of perpendicular lines?

subsection.title: Equations for Horizontal and Vertical Lines
subsection.p: In Lesson 3.3 we learned that the slope of a horizontal line is zero. What does this tell us about the equation of a horizontal line that passes through a particular point?

statement.p: Find the equation of the horizontal line that passes through (5,3).

solution.p: Looking at the graph of the line shown below, we see that the y-coordinate of every point on the line is 3.

In particular, the y-intercept of the line is the point (0,3), so b=3. As we noted above, the slope of the line is m=0. Substituting these values into the slope-intercept form gives us the equation y= 0 \cdot x + 3 or just y=3. The fact that x does not appear in the equation means that y=3 for every point on the line, no matter what the value of x is.

assemblage.title: Look Closer
assemblage.p: What about the equation of a vertical line? The slope of a vertical line is undefined; a vertical line does not have a slope. We cannot use the slope-intercept form to write the equation of a vertical line. However, we can use what we learned about horizontal lines in Example 2.

sidebyside.p: Look at the graph of the vertical line at right. Every point on the line has x-coordinate -2, no matter what the y-coordinate is. An equation for this line is x=-2. The value of x does not depend upon y; it is constant, so y does not appear in the equation.

note.p:
We make two observations about the examples above.
The y-intercept of the horizontal line y=3 is (0,3); it has no x-intercept.
The x-intercept of the vertical line x=-2 is (-2,0); it has no y-intercept.

li.p: The equation of the horizontal line passing through (0,b) is \blert{y=b}
The equation of the vertical line passing through (a,0) is \blert{x=a}

warning.p:
The equation for a line is not the same thing as the slope of the line!
The slope of every horizontal line is zero, but the equation of a horizontal line has the form y=b, where b is the y-coordinate of every point on the line.
Similarly, the equation of a vertical line has the form x=a, but the slope of a vertical line is undefined.

statement.p: Give an example of an equation of a vertical line.
Give an example of an equation of a horizontal line.

subsection.title: Distance Between Points
subsection.p: It is easy to compute the distance between two points that lie on the same horizontal or vertical line. We subtract the smaller coordinate from the larger one.

sidebyside.p: The distance between the points A(6, \blert{5}) and B(6, \blert{-7}) in the figure is \Delta y = 5-(-7)=12 and the distance between points C(\blert{-7}, -3) and D(\blert{-2}, -3) is \Delta x = -2-(-7)=5

image.description: a vertical segment and a horizontal segment

subsection.p: Note that the distance between two points is always a positive number. That is why we always subtract the smaller coordinate from the larger one to compute distance. However, when we compute a slope, we need more information.

assemblage.title: Look Closer
assemblage.p: When we compute slope, the direction in which we move on the line makes a difference. We will call this the directed distance, and it can be either positive or negative.

If we move from C to D, we have moved in the positive x-direction, so the directed distance is positive: \Delta x = -2-(-7)=5 If we move from D to C, we have moved in the negative x-direction, so the directed distance is negative: \Delta x = -7-(-2)=-5
To find the directed distance between two points on a number line, we subtract the initial coordinate from the final coordinate.

statement.p: How do we find the distance between two points that lie on the same vertical line?

answer.p: Subtract the smaller y-coordinate from the larger one

statement.p: A directed distance can be either or .

assemblage.title: Look Ahead
assemblage.p: So far we have computed the slope of a line by finding \Delta x and \Delta y on the graph. Now we can use directed distance to develop a formula for slope.

sidebyside.p:
Compute the slope of the line segment joining P and R in two ways:
Find \Delta y and \Delta x using the graph
Find \Delta y and \Delta x using coordinates.

subsection.title: Subscript Notation
subsection.p: When we compute the slope of a line joining two points, we must be careful to subtract their x-coordinates and their y-coordinates in the same order, final minus initial. To distinguish between the coordinates of different points, we use a new notation called subscripts.

assemblage.p: We denote the coordinates of a particular point by (x_1,y_1) and the coordinates of a second point by (x_2,y_2).

sidebyside.p: Compute the slope between point D and F in the figure.

solution.p:
We'll call D the first point and F the second point. Then their coordinates are
D:~~~x_1 \amp =-6 \amp\amp \text{and}\amp y_1 \amp =-2 F:~~~x_2 \amp = 9 \amp\amp \text{and}\amp y_2 \amp =4 Now we can describe the formula for slope in an organized way. We compute \Delta y and \Delta x as directed distances. First, we observe that the coordinates of point E are (-6,4) or (x_1,y_2). From the figure, we can see that \Delta y = y_2-y_1 = 4-(-2)=6 and \Delta x = x_2-x_1 = 9-(-6)=15 Thus, the slope of the line segment joining D and F is m=\dfrac{y_2-y_1}{x_2-x_1} = \dfrac{6}{15} = \dfrac{2}{5}

warning.p: The subscript 1 on x_1, for instance, has nothing to do with the value of the coordinate; it merely identifies this coordinate as the x-coordinate of the first point.

statement.p: What do the subscripts in (x_1,y_1) mean?
Write a formula for computing \Delta y.

subsection.title: A New Formula for Slope
subsection.p: The method described in Example 5 gives us a new formula for computing slope.

assemblage.title: Two-Point Formula for Slope
assemblage.p: The slope of the line joining points P_1(x_1,y_1) and P_2(x_2,y_2) is \blert{m=\dfrac{y_2-y_1}{x_2-x_1}}~~~~~~\text{if}~~~~x_2 \not= x_1

subsection.p: We don't need a graph in order to use this formula, just the coordinates of two points on the line.

statement.p: Compute the slope of the line joining the points (6,-2) and (3,-1).
What is wrong with this formula for slope: m = \dfrac{y_2-y_1}{x_1-x_2}?

answer.p: The x- and y-coordinates hould be subtracted in the same order.

introduction.p: For Problems 1-8, find the negative reciprocal.
